title: Vale of Kent
text:
The Vale of Kent, located in <a href="Kent">Kent</a>, <a href="England">England</a>, is the name given to the broad clay <a href="River%20valley">vale</a> between the <a href="Greensand%20Ridge">Greensand Ridge</a> and the <a href="Weald">High Weald</a>. The area is drained by a number of <a href="Rivers%20of%20Kent">rivers</a>, including the <a href="River%20Beult">Beult</a>, <a href="River%20Eden%2C%20Kent">Eden</a> <a href="River%20Medway">Medway</a>, <a href="River%20Stour%2C%20Kent">Stour</a> and <a href="River%20Teise">River Teise</a>.
Principal settlements in the Vale include <a href="Ashford%2C%20Kent">Ashford</a> and <a href="Tonbridge">Tonbridge</a>.
Geology.
The Weald is the eroded remains of a geological structure, an <a href="anticline">anticline</a>, a dome of layered <a href="Lower%20Cretaceous">Lower Cretaceous</a> <a href="Rock%20%28geology%29">rock</a>s cut through by <a href="erosion">erosion</a> to expose the layers as <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a> ridges and <a href="clay">clay</a> valleys. The oldest rocks exposed at the centre of the anticline are correlated with the <a href="Purbeck%20Beds">Purbeck Beds</a> of the <a href="Upper%20Jurassic">Upper Jurassic</a>. Above these, the Cretaceous rocks, include the <a href="Wealden%20Group">Wealden Group</a> of alternating sands and clays - the Ashdown Sand, Wadhurst Clay, Tunbridge Wells Sand (collectively known as the Hastings Beds) and the Weald Clay. The Wealden Group is overlain by the <a href="Lower%20Greensand">Lower Greensand</a> and the Gault Formation, consisting of the <a href="Gault%20Clay">Gault Clay</a> and the <a href="Upper%20Greensand">Upper Greensand</a>.
The rocks of the central part of the anticline include hard sandstones, and these form hills now called the "High Weald". The peripheral areas are mostly of softer sandstones and clays and these form the gentler rolling landscape of "Low Weald", of which the Vale of Kent is a part. The <a href="Weald-Artois%20Anticline">Weald-Artois Anticline</a> continues some further south-eastwards under the <a href="Straits%20of%20Dover">Straits of Dover</a>, and includes the <a href="Boulonnais%20%28land%20area%29">Boulonnais</a> of <a href="France">France</a>.
